title: Miley Cyrus Toasts Art With “Pure Heart and Pure Love” at Vanity Fair and the Four Seasons’ 2nd Annual Directors Dinner
article_text: On Thursday night, amid the buzz of the 24thTribeca Film Festival, nearly two dozen directors gathered at theFour Seasons Hotel New York Downtownto fête their recent projects.Vanity Fairhosted the second annual Directors Dinner, celebrating excellence in entertainment, at CUT byWolfgang Puck,the legendary California chef’s first New York City outpost. Over tartlets and glasses of Dom Pérignon Vintage 2015 – Jean-Michel Basquiat Special Edition, the guests chatted withVFacting editor in chiefDaniel Kileand Condé Nast global head of film and televisionHelen Estabrook,before taking their seats under the striking art in the restaurant’s dining room. Miley Cyrus,the night’s special guest, is premiering her pop opera,Something Beautiful,at the festival tonight. It’s a visual accompaniment to heralbum of the same name, which was released last week. Before sitting down for dinner, she explained the title’s significance. “It’s a name that really embodies what everyone here was wanting and inspired to create,” Cyrus said. “What we’re putting out into the universe, it’s medicine for a sick culture. When we do it with pure intentions, a pure heart, and pure love, I really do believe that it is medicine.” During the cocktail hour,Mariska Hargitayand her husbandPeter Herrmancaught up with comedianJim Gaffigan.Hargitay’s powerful documentary,My Mom Jayne,premiered at Cannes last month to rapturous audience response. In it, she grapples with the legacy of her mother, Jayne Mansfield, and her discovery as an adult that Mickey Hargitay, the parent who raised her, was not her biological father. In his remarks, Kile praised Hargitay’s work and explained whyVFdecided to turnlast year’s partyinto an annual event. “We got so much out of it that we decided to do it again here, bigger and better than before,” he said. “We’re so honored to have so many filmmakers, speakers, jury members, and producers of projects out tonight.” Cyrus was joined by her codirectors,Jacob BixenmanandBrendan Walter,and the film’s producer,Panos Cosmatos,as well as her musical collaborator,Shawn Everett.In advance of Cyrus’s arrival with boyfriend and fellow musicianMaxx Morando,Cosmatos reflected on the process of makingSomething Beautiful,tellingVFthat he was able to join Cyrus in the studio as its songs were coming together. The night attendees also included actorsStephanie Hsu, Mary Beth Barone,andMamie Gummer;Tribeca jury membersMarianne Jean-Baptiste, Nia DaCosta,andEliza Hittman;and galleristVito Schnabeland his wife,Helena.Annie Murphycaught up withMary Hollis Inboden,while directorsLiz GarbusandRy Russo-Youngtraded compliments about each other’s recent work.Patricia Arquette,whose directorial debut,Gonzo Girl,will have its US premiere during the festival, was seated at Kile’s table alongside friendLuke Anderson. A common topic of conversation was dressing for the abnormally intense Manhattan humidity. Fashion designerCynthia Rowleyand comedianMichael Ian Blackchatted about his reflective blazer, while AMPAS presidentJanet Yangand filmmakerBing Chendiscussed how to best wear a tie in the summer weather. DirectorElegance Brattonand producerChester Gordon,whose new filmMove Ya Body: The Birth of Housepremieres next weekend, discussed making a film about the genre of music they both love. DirectorAngela Lynn Tuckerspoke aboutThe Inquisitor,her documentary portrait of Congresswoman Barbara Jordan, and finding hope for the future while combing through archival material of a different era. Guests admired aTracey Emininstallation flanking the restaurant’s bar, made of lightning flashes of red neon. They were served an appropriately aesthetic champagne: Dom Pérignon Vintage 2015 – Tribute to Jean-Michel Basquiat, in bottles featuring the iconic painter’s signature crown motif. This event is part of an ongoing series of Hollywood film premiere parties, cast toasts, and entertainment-industry dinner conversations thatVanity Fairand Four Seasons are convening around the world in 2025, including events in New York, Paris, London, and at the Toronto International Film Festival. Four Seasons celebrates luxury destinations through film and television to authentically showcase the beauty, culture, and heritage of its properties to a global audience. title: David Beckham, The Royal Family’s Biggest Fan, Is Finally Getting Inducted Into Their Special Club
article_text: For years,David Beckham,a national treasure in the UK, has gone without beinggranted knighthood, the title that cements one’s status as a British legend. But next week,King Charles IIIwill share his birthday honors list, the biannual summary of changes to the system with knighthood at its pinnacle, and according toThe Sun,this year is finally Beckham’s chance to join the historic royal club. The tabloid notes that even though this year’s honorees are not yet public, private letters have already gone out to the recipients. Ever since retiring from soccer in 2013, the 50-year-old has pursued business deals, raised a family with wifeVictoria Beckham,built up a philanthropic legacy, and gotten close to the British royal family. In September 2022, the self-described “huge royalist” even waited 13 hours in the queue to see Queen Elizabeth’s casket as she was lying in state. Over the last few years, Beckham has been a reliable presence at royal engagements, evenexchanging honey with the kingand joiningPrince Williamfora helicopter photo shoot. In 2024 he made the affiliation official when he became an ambassador for the King’s Foundation, the youth-empowerment charity Charles founded as a young Prince of Wales in 1976. “I’m excited to be working with The King’s Foundation and to have the opportunity to help raise awareness of the charity’s work,” Beckham said ina statementat the time. “I’ve always been keen to help young people to expand their horizons and I’m particularly looking forward to supporting the Foundation’s education programs and its efforts to ensure young people have greater access to nature.” The UK honors system, which dates back centuries, awards prominent Brits with a tiered series of medals to commend their contributions to public life. While serving as the captain of the England national team, Beckham received the medal for the Order of the British Empire, the second rung on the ladder to knighthood, from the late queenin 2003. There isno set timelinefor knighthood after a person has received an OBE, and many who receive the initial honor do not go on to receive the final one. Beckham celebrated his milestone birthday recently witha series of parties in London. The reporting following one of those parties revealed that Victoria and David’s oldest son,Brooklyn Beckham,has been making a few new royal friendships of his own. Thehot-sauce entrepreneurand his wife ofthree years,Nicola Peltz,reportedly went to a dinner party withPrince HarryandMeghan Markleinstead of attending his father’s birthday celebrations. Peoplereports that the party took place at the home of Paramount Pictures CEOBrian Robbinsand his wife,Tracy Robbins.“Brooklyn and Nicola were invited prior to David’s numerous global birthday galas, so the timing is pure coincidence,” a source told the magazine. “Brooklyn and Nicola had a wonderful time and found Harry and Meghan to be particularly kind, caring and generous.” Your Guide to the2025 Tony Awards An Exclusive First Look atWicked: For Good The Chaos InsideJohnny Depp and Amber Heard’s Wedding What Is Going On WithPatti LuPone? title: When Megalomaniacs Collide: Trump Threatens to Ditch His Tesla as War with Musk Goes Nuclear
article_text: The countdown toElon MuskandDonald Trump’s epic fallout started as soon as their bromance began. Long before the chainsaws and the spurious salutes, there was always only one way that an alliance between two megalomaniacal billionaires who see themselves as society’s saviors was going to end. And now, here we are. After days of holding his fire in the face ofMusk’s online tiradeagainst the GOP spending bill,Trump fired backThursday, threatening on Truth Social to “terminate Elon’s Governmental Subsidies and Contracts,” which he said would be the “easiest way to save money in our Budget, Billions and Billions of Dollars.” He's also—gasp!—reportedly consideringselling his Tesla. Trump—who just one week ago during an Oval Office sendoff insisted that Musk was“not really leaving”the administration —wrote thathe asked Musk to leaveafter “he just went CRAZY” over Trump’s push to end electric vehicle tax credits in the GOP bill. Trump’s allies, meanwhile, are pushing for even more retaliatory measures.Steve Bannontold Politicothat the feds should investigate Musk’s immigration status, alleged drug use, and connections to China, and “seize both SpaceX and Starlink and put them under government management until that time that all investigations into Musk are complete.” And how did the target of these threats respond? Byposting a seriesofraised eyebrow emojisabout alleged ties between Trump andJeffrey Epstein. One thing is clear: Trump and Musk are now on a path of mutually assured destruction. Over the course of the day Thursday,Axios reportsboth Trump Media and Tesla lost billions of dollars in value. Since the election, the most powerful people in business have been silent as Trump disrupted the economy with his tariffs and trade wars. The richest men in tech have uttered not a peep as the administration has eviscerated the universities whose research they rely on and sent foreign researchers packing. Who knew it would be the chief financier of the Trump administration and the pied piper of the new tech right who would be the first to publicly oppose Trump? But Musk seems to have something thatTim Cook,Mark Zuckerberg,Sundar Pichai, Jeff Bezosand others don’t: Comfort with chaos. Musk is the only one who has proven himself eminently willing to burn his own house down. This is the same guy who riskedan SEC investigationinto securities fraudover a 420 joke, who lit$44 billion on fireto buy Twitter, and whosacrificed Tesla’s revenue and reputationto go all in on DOGE. Musk appears to believe that he has enough political clout to withstand a split with MAGA. In a poll on X,Musk askedThursday whether it's time to create “a new political party in America that actually represents the 80% in the middle?” As of Friday morning, more than 80% of respondents had answered “yes.” Of course, the irony is that Musk, a free-speech absolutist, is now getting a first hand look at how the man he ushered into office actually treats the people who speak out against him. Billionaires, they're just like us. title: After Arriving in New York City, Princess Leonor Heads to Carnegie Hall
article_text: On Thursday,Princess Leonor, heir to the Spanish throne, attended a concert at Carnegie Hall in New York. Accompanied by the rest of the midshipmen, the Princess of Asturias enjoyedA Musical Fantasy from Spain.The program included works by Manuel de Falla and Maurice Ravel and zarzuela pieces performed by the sopranoSaioa Hernández, who made her debut in the mythical New York hall. Another of the attractions of the concert was the performance of violinistMaría Dueñas, who played Wolfgang Korngold's Concerto for Violin and Orchestra in D major. Official photographs of the event show Princess Leonor in the stalls of Carnegie Hall, seated with her fellow midshipmen and dressed like them in the Navy's white uniform of special prominence. Prior to the concert, the midshipmen also attended a reception and dinner where they posed for a group photo on the roof of the building. The princess also posed for a photo with the group of female midshipmen who have been part of this cruise of the Juan Sebastián de Elcano. This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. This is the first activity which Princess Leonor has taken part in New York afterher arrival at the port of the city last Wednesday. Before returning by plane to Spain on June 10, the Princess of Asturias and her companions are expected to participate in other events, such as the swearing in of the flag aboard the training ship or a meeting with Spaniards, which according to¡Hola!will be joined by the Duchess of Medinaceli,Victoria de Hohenlohe, who has been living in New York for some time due to her husband's work. For the moment, it has not been announced that any member of the Royal Family will travel to New York to accompany Leonor on this last stop of the Juan Sebastián de Elcano. Queen Sofiapresided over one of the Royal Theater's previous concerts at Carnegie Hall in 2022, and also usually travels to the city as honorary president of the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute, so there had been speculation that she might go to meet her granddaughter there. title: The Birkin Bag That Started It All Heads to Auction
article_text: If you had to keep just one object to tell the story of the last 40 years of fashion, it could fit in one hand -- or on one arm, worn nonchalantly like its original muse. It's not a bag, it'sthebag. Created following a now mythical Paris-London flight, thevery first Birkin bagimagined by Jean-Louis Dumas (former president ofHermès) forJane Birkinin 1984 will be auctioned by Sotheby's at its first “Fashion Icons” sale in Paris on July 10. More than an accessory, this prototype is a relic. A unique piece with the patina of an icon's life. Marked with her initials "J.B.", it features an unexpected detail: nail clippers suspended from a chain. It has to be said that Jane Birkin has never been one to overdo luxury. It was precisely this contrast that forged the Birkin legend. A bag born of chance, from the charming disorder of an airline flight, which became the most coveted model in the history of leather goods. Before crocodile skin, diamond inlays and endless waiting lists, there was this model. The original Birkin differs from those subsequently marketed. It has the width and height of a Birkin 35 with the depth of a Birkin 40, closed metal rings as on the house's high strap model, gold-plated brass details that would later be replaced by gold, rose gold, palladium or ruthenium jewelry. But also a shoulder strap sewn in one piece (which would never be the case again) and a “vintage zipper.” Each detail recounts a moment of transition between bespoke craftsmanship and standardized luxury goods. The details. The shoulder strap. The inside zipper. The nail clippers. This bag was well worn by Jane Birkin. The singer and actress couldn't stand bags that were too small, and once carried around a bag she didn't think suited her lifestyle. That is, until its contents - diapers, cigarettes, glasses, notebooks - were scattered all over the CEO of Hermès, who happened to be sitting next to her on the plane. He asked her to draw her ideal bag... on a sickness bag. The rest is history. This famous Birkin is not just a prototype, it's ground zero of contemporary luxury fantasy. The skillful blend of rarity, storytelling and heritage that made the myth of the French label. Hermès produces only a limited number each year, sold only to the most loyal (or patient) customers. Obtaining a Birkin is often an initiation process. It's hardly surprising, then, that this very first model should be the object of much envy. It has already been sold twice. The first, by Jane herself, in aid of Solidarité Sida in 1994. Then again in 2000, when it joined the private collection ofCatherine Benier, founder of vintage boutique Les 3 Marches in Paris. MorganeHalimi, head of fashion collections at Sotheby's, believes that it is "rare [...] for an object to transcend trends and become a legend": "Jane Birkin's original Birkin bag is one of those. A true unicorn in the world of fashion and accessories, this iconic handbag stands side by side with other exceptional items of equally dazzling provenance - such asPrincess Diana's symbolic black sheep sweaterand Freddie Mercury's crown and cape. Both set exceptional benchmarks for items of their kind. Like them, the original Birkin has the potential to redefine records, but above all, our priority is to ensure that it finds a new home worthy of its iconic status and legendary history." The bag will be on display at Sotheby's in New York from June 6 to 12, then on view in Paris on rue du Faubourg St Honoré from July 3 to 9. It will then be auctioned on the 10th, alongside other iconic fashion items from famous couture shows by Alexander McQueen, Christian Dior, John Galliano, Thierry Mugler and Azzedine Alaïa. Jane Birkin's original Birkin bag (on base) next to the new standard Birkin design. The auction house has not yet given an estimated price. However, precedents such as the Birkin Himalaya sold for $513,000 in Hong Kong in 2017. The original Birkin, with its strong history and provenance, could lay claim to this record. All the more so as the object today transcends its status as an accessory: exhibited at MoMA in New York and the V&A Museum in London, it now belongs to the pantheon of global visual culture. Jane Birkin, who died in 2023, sometimes joked that she might be remembered not for her films orJe t'aime... moi non plus, but for this bag. What she didn't know was that the fashion world hadn't simply adopted the Birkin: it had sanctified it. title: The One True Andy Kaufman: A New Doc Uses Private Tapes to Capture His Genius, Kindness, and Chaos
article_text: Who was the real Andy Kaufman? It’s a question that had people scratching their heads even before the actor/performance artist—who was often pigeonholed as being a comedian, much to his own chagrin—passed away in 1984 at the age of 35. Within his too-short lifetime, theTaxistar managed to pack in a lifetime’s worth of rich material that we’re still analyzing today. Whether he was lip-synching theMighty Mousetheme song—specifically, the chorus—wrestling women as the self-proclaimed Intergender Wrestling Champion of the World, readingThe Great Gatsbyin itsentiretyto an audience, crooning as an obnoxious lounge singer named Tony Clifton, or taking the entire audience of Carnegie Hall out for milk and cookies, Kaufman is still keeping us guessing as to what is and isn’t real. The thing is, how you view Kaufman can change depending on who you ask. For instance, he himself always said he was “just a song and dance man.” His secretary,Linda Mitchell,has said that he told her he aspired to be “the greatest entertainer of all time.”David Lettermantells me that spending time with Andy was like, “spending a day at the carnival.” FilmmakerClay Tweelsees him as being “someone who is very sweet and full of contrast.” Longtime admirerDwayne Johnsonrefers to Kaufman as being “the epitome of humanity in that it takes guts to go down the road that Andy went down.” To his sisterCarol Kaufman-Kerman,he was simply “a gentle man who genuinely loved his family.” Now, Tweel’s new documentary—Andy Kaufman Is Me—premieres tonight at the Tribeca Film Festival. The film attempts to pull back the curtain and show a side of Kaufman that audiences may be unfamiliar with: the man behind the meticulously calculated chaos that he relished in making you believe was genuine, off-the-rails chaos. “I remember seeing oldSNLclips when I was little of Andy,” Tweel says of his first exposure to the gifted performer. “And he struck me as strange and sort of gave me uncomfortable feelings, but I liked it and I didn’t know why. I love being able to understand people who are the best at what they do, what their creative juices look like. Trying to get inside their brain.” There’s been countless books written about Kaufman, a major motion picture starringJim Carrey,TV retrospectives, a podcast, a long-running award devoted to preserving his legacy, and even an entire college course at DePaul University in Chicago dedicated to his work. But there hadn’t been a comprehensive documentary that adequately covered the scope of his life and career. Kaufman’s family knew there was a story there left to tell. Says Tweel, “I’ll never forget my first conversation with the Kaufman family. They were talking about how there was parts of Andy that the public never got to see. And my first question was ‘How are we going to be able to show that? It’s a visual medium. What’re we going to do?’ And that’s when they told me about the 84 hours of audio tapes.” From 1977 until 1982, Kaufman kept a tape recorder rolling in his coat pocket. Some would know they were being recorded. Most would not. According to Kaufman’s brother,Michael Kaufman,“He wasn’t doing it for a purpose. He wasn’t doing it for legacy. He was just having fun. And look at the results. It allowed memories to be rekindled.” For Kaufman, this was an act of self-expression. And he was able to do it without the gatekeepers of the TV or film industry telling him he couldn’t. He had complete control over his tape recorder. As his sister Carol says, “Self-expression was so important to him in his life. And on the flip side: the lack of self-expression—when he was voted offSNL,when he was prevented from going to the Maharishi workshops, when he wasn’t invited to other television shows—was also a detriment to his health.” He would record conversations with fans, including those who wrote him hate letters, who he would personally call. (He would always tell Letterman, “Send me the hate mail,” after he did hisLate Nightshow). He would record moments of fun singing in the car with his family, or heartfelt conversations with his grandma, Lillie, whom he loved so dearly that he would wear a shirt that says “I Love Grandma” while onstage. He would record prank phone calls made to the restaurant he worked at as a busboy, mundane conversations with those in his life that seem to go nowhere, and interactions with hitchhikers he picked up. Once, he recorded hours of material as a character he was playing in a movie. He wanted to go somewhere where he wouldn’t be recognized, so he flew to London and stood in Hyde Park where he would claim to be God in a thick Southern drawl. Moments that would otherwise be lost to time were just waiting to be unearthed. “In my opinion, [the 84 hours of audio] took the documentary to another level,” says Dwayne Johnson, who is a producer on the film via his production company, Seven Bucks Productions. “When you just hear him speak at times, he’s so vulnerable and open.” Adds Carol, “The first time I heard the tapes, I felt like I was hanging onto Andy and the brotherly love. When Andy got busy and famous, he couldn’t give me the same time as when we were much younger and living together in a house. I did this search of ‘How did Andy relate to me? Did he still love me? Was I still important to him as his kid sister?’ So when I heard these recordings [which featured Andy and his sister talking on the phone, with her not knowing she was being recorded], I was very emotional because it was so tender and loving. I could feel our closeness and how easily we could speak about personal things. How he was interested in my life.” Kaufman is often heralded as being ahead of his time. When people say that, they’re speaking specifically to his professional output. But on these audio tapes, you realize that he was also a pioneer of capturing everyday moments as they unfolded, much like what you might find on social media today. These tapes represent a fascination with catching raw and real emotions during a time when the only output for something like that would’ve been onCandid Camera.It was just another way for Kaufman to orchestrate his own narrative and bring his ultimate fantasy world to life. As unpredictable as things might have looked when he was onFridaysand pouring water onMichael Richards’s head, for instance, everything he did was completely by design. There were no accidents with Andy. And unlikeSacha Baron Cohen’sBoratis that—a lot of times—he’d even let the other person in on it. “One of many nice things about Andy is you would get a rough outline,” says Letterman, an executive producer of the new documentary via Worldwide Pants. “It was like a menu at Denny’s. He would tell you what he was up to, generally. So there were never any surprises, except that the performance that he had outlined was always interesting and exciting.” The audio archives that Tweel had access to aren’t limited to just Andy’s personal recordings either. Featured in the film are archival audios used for Bill Zehme’s 1999 book,Lost in the Funhouse. Through this archival audio, Andy’s father, Stanley—who passed in 2013—is able to shed light on his relationship with his son, which was occasionally strained when Andy was a teenager. He even shares a letter that Andy wrote to him a few years before his big break onSaturday Night Livethat really paints a picture of not just the regard that Andy held his family in, but his determination to make it in show business and the big things that he had on the horizon. Tweel told me that Zehme’s tapes were important because “sometimes audio interviews are a little more candid and a little more honest because people have dropped the pretenses that a video camera brings.” Another way of showing this different side of Kaufman was through his writing. As his brother Michael says in the film, “We love Andy as a performance artist and an entertainer. But we only get a small part of who is really there. As big as Andy is, you only get to see a small part of him. But to read his writings, you get to see so much more of that creative brain.” When Andy died, he had been writing a novel that was, in many ways, his magnum opus,The Huey Williams Story.It is an epic told in four-parts, the first being autobiographical. This was the work that Andy always said he was proudest of. It was his most personal, and it was also, sadly, something that he didn’t get to finish before his death. (The book was later released as-is posthumously.) If you’re looking to really get a glimpse into how Kaufman saw the world and just how his mind worked, all roads lead back toHuey. The issue with featuring writings in a documentary, however, is that you’re sort of limited to featuring someone else’s narration. Luckily, before he put pen to paper, Andy talked out the entirety ofThe Huey Williams Storywhile staying at a hotel during a meditation retreat. This audio served as a way to bring Huey to life to help tell Andy’s story. Tweel broke the documentary into four parts and utilized puppets for this portion of the film. “For me, it was the moment of being able to see how much Andy used puppetry in his own act,” the director says about his inspiration for using puppets from the Bob Baker Theater in Los Angeles to tell Andy’s story. “I did not totally realize until I sat down and was watching all of the archive together at once, ‘Man this keeps coming back up.’ It was probably the funnest two-day shoot I’ve ever done in my career—being able to create a world of Fellini/Andy Kaufman puppets to try and bring Huey Williams to life.” One of the most talked about moments of Kaufman’s career is the wrestling, of course. He had been fascinated with wrestling ever since he was a kid, when his dad took him to see a match at Madison Square Garden the night Buddy Rogers lost his World Championship title. Wrestling would become a big part of his professional life when he started grappling with women onstage. In the documentary, you get to learn just how significant this moment of his career was for Andy: It was a chance for him to live out his childhood fantasies of professional wrestling, and he took the opportunity to play the villain. “At the time, wrestling certainly wasn’t the global business that it is today,” says Johnson. “So any kind of exposure on national television was always a big deal in the world of wrestling, especially when Andy went down to the company that Jerry Lawler was a part of [in Memphis]. And that was a company, USWA, that my dad wrestled at. That was a company that I wrestled at. So it was big exciting news in the world of pro wrestling that this celebrity from outside, this television star fromTaxiand fromSaturday Night Livewas involved in wrestling and giving professional wrestling the rub, if you will.” Andy’s time in the ring reached new heights when he went head-to-head with a man for the first time—Jerry “The King” Lawler in Memphis on April 5, 1982. The match got widespread national attention due to Andy’s celebrity, particularly because Lawler gave him the “piledriver,” which led to him being in the hospital for three days. Then purely for added theatrics, Kaufman and Lawler were later reunited onLate Nightwith Letterman. Letterman recalls, “I saw the documentary two nights ago. And whenever I see Andy and Jerry Lawler, it’s always exactly as I remember it. Which is interesting because most often your memory deletes things or adds things that did not happen or were unnecessary. But my memory of that is exactly how it unfolded when Andy got slapped by Lawler. The very next day, the account of this is inThe New YorkTimes.And it refers to Andy as Mr. Kaufman and Jerry Lawler as Mr. Lawler. And they’re talking about this ridiculous stint on a TV show.” The same guy who played “bad guy wrestler,” and donned a mustache as the obnoxious singer Tony Clifton—which Kaufman’s brother calls “the best therapy you could do”— would go on to insist that his childhood hero, Howdy Doody, appear in his 1979 ABC special. In the documentary, you learn just how significant it was for Kaufman to share a tender and heartfelt moment with Howdy Doody. It may be the most vulnerable that Andy ever allowed himself to be on camera. Says Tweel of that moment, “Showing that allowed us to show that this boy, who perhaps spent a lot of time by himself in his room when he was little and was a little bit isolated, truly could’ve formed a very unique connection with the people on TV, including this puppet.” “It’s one of those rare moments where you see something so authentic,” says Michael. “Because most art is exaggerated. But that’s one piece of art that was never exaggerated in any way. It wasn’t even fantasy. It was just reality. It doesn’t matter whether the person is inanimate or not. It’s just his childhood hero.” Even though you couldn’t always see it in his performances, vulnerability was a consistent thread within whatever he did. He put so much of himself into what he was creating, even if he was playing a character that wasn’t himself. When he’s playing the lovable Foreign Man who couldn’t tell a joke to save his life, for instance, there was truth in that. Kaufman was always the first to admit that he never told a joke, despite being pigeonholed as a “comedian.” “Vulnerability,” Johnson says, “was always percolating with him from what I’m told. He put himself in these positions where he could have fun and he could get lost in these characters.” Even as you’re watching all of this archival footage that’s been unearthed for the documentary, you wonder if there’s more—and there always is, of course. An hour and 41 minutes doesn’t even scratch the surface of capturing the entirety of a standard person’s essence. In the case of someone like Kaufman, who’s made a career out of keeping the audience guessing, perhaps the fact that we still have questions is exactly what he would want. Why should we have all of the answers, anyway? But of course, there is that selfish part of us that always wants to know more. “Isn’t this all about trying to figure Andy out?” his sister asks in the documentary. “Are we trying to get some clarity on who Andy is? Because even in trying to get that definition of who Andy is, there’s a sense of containment in defining somebody. And Andy was not interested in being remembered as just one thing. And aren’t we all so much more complex? Which makes Andy in a way not just unique, but like the same of all of us.” “Everything he did was real,” his brother Michael assures me. “He operated from the gut. I don’t know anyone more real than Andy. But it was all real because Andy didn’t do anything to get someone’s approval.” In retrospect, those who were lucky enough to find themselves in Kaufman’s orbit realize what a special chance it was to get to go on a journey with him. That’s a constant thread you’ll find in not just the documentary, but also anytime people talk about him in retrospective interviews in the last 40-plus years: You can’t talk about the guy without mentioning the word “fun.” As Letterman sees it, “For a guy that made the kind of impact that he did, that was very satisfying to him to have created this character that was so multi-faceted and inexplicable and to some people repulsive and to other people joyful. That’s a pretty good accomplishment by the time you’re 35.” For Tweel, the director, the quest to figure out who Kaufman was comes back to the man himself. So, in the new documentary, the subject of all this guesswork speaks for himself, both in writing and in the audio tapes. That is how you get to know Andy. “I always try to be as empathetic and try to understand people as best I can,” Tweel says. “And try to humanize them. So that played out in a way with this film. Let Andy try to humanize himself and talk for himself in a way he hasn’t before.” In addition to his work in journalism, Andrew Buss has been the official Andy Kaufman archivist/historian since 2015. He was an archival consultant onAndy Kaufman Is Me,and has the distinction of having listened to all 84 hours of Kaufman’s audio tapes. title: Jason Segel and Kristen Bell Will Always Remember 'Forgetting Sarah Marshall'
article_text: InReunited,Awards Insider hosts a conversation between two Emmy contenders who have collaborated on a previous project. Who would have thought that a raunchy comedy featuring a naked breakup scene and a Dracula musical would change everything for its two lead actors? The 2008 comedyForgetting Sarah Marshall,about a freshly dumped guy who takes a solo vacation to Hawaii and discovers his ex is at the same resort with her new fling, did just that forJason SegelandKristen Bell. At the time, Bell had been playing a teen detective on the TV seriesVeronica Mars,but wasn’t known as a comedic heavyweight. After playing Sarah Marshall, she went on to star in films likeCouples RetreatandBad Moms,as well as the beloved Emmy-nominated seriesThe Good Place. Segel had built up a notable acting career, having starred on the TV seriesFreaks and Geeks,Undeclared,andHow I Met Your Mother—butForgetting Sarah Marshall,which he wrote andNicholas Stollerdirected, launched his career as a writer. He and Stoller later collaborated on the scripts forThe Muppets, The Five-Year Engagement,andSex Tape,with Segel also starring in all of them. “We’re coming up on 20 years,” says Segel, looking back onSarah Marshall.“It feels like a lifetime ago. We were all probably different people.” But when Segel and Bell get together over Zoom for this Reunited conversation, they quickly discover that a lot of things haven’t changed. Segel, now the lead actor and cocreator of the Apple TV+ seriesShrinking,is still pushing the envelope while giving everyone inhis castmoments to shine. He’s already earned an Emmy nomination for playing Jimmy, a therapist who is grappling with his own grief; in season two, he blossoms in his performance as an awkward man with big feelings. Bell currently stars on the hit Netflix seriesNobody Wants This,playing an agnostic podcaster who falls for a Jewish rabbi (Adam Brody). The role showcases her agile comedic abilities and undeniable charisma, making you root for her character even as she’s sifting through the chaos of her dating and family life. After a breakout first season that earned Bell nominations at the Golden Globes, SAG Awards, and Critics Choice Awards, the rom-com has been renewed fora second seasonthat will debut on October 23. Here, Bell and Segel look back on the wild days of filmingForgetting Sarah Marshallin Hawaii, explain why a script is “like a treasure map,” and share what type of out-of-the-box role they’re each still hoping to take on in the future. Segel and Bell inForgetting Sarah Marshall Vanity Fair:What do you remember about the first time you met? Jason Segel:I remember the process of castingSarah Marshall.We had developed this ethos that just because two people are great actors separately doesn’t necessarily mean that they’re going to have chemistry. So it wasn’t about just offering it to an actor we admired—it was getting in a room and seeing if you improv well together, if the vibe is there. We read together. Kristen is not going to let you sink with theTitanicin an improv scene—she will go down with you. It’s a ride or die. And that’s the only way to do that kind of process. You have to have this faith that at the end, in the editing, no one’s going to make you look dumb. And it was pretty instant. Like, Oh, that’s our lady. Kristen Bell:That’s incredibly flattering to hear, because I’ll tell you—I was so tired. So scared. I also saw famous people in the waiting room and I thought, Well, what are you doing here? I felt so dejected. The only thing I clung to was, You can be open. I’m not trained in improv by any sense of the word, but I’ve seen people do it, and I tried to pick things up here and there. Segel:The advantage I think that you had by not having a lot of improv experience is that there is an improv trap: You think your job is to be funny. You think your job is to show off how many different clever responses you have. It ends up being self-indulgent. At the end of the day, you can only use one [take], and you’re going to use the one that’s generally the most honest—especially if you’re the main character. There are some side characters whose job it is to be a fucking joke assassin and come in with the funniest thing you’ve ever heard, but when you’re the main character, your job is to drive story. How high were the stakes for you for this movie to work? Segel:I was a kid. I think I was 25 when I wrote the movie, and 27 by the time it came out. So there are two things going on: One is you’re getting your shot, and so there are the stakes to that. But there was also this naivete of youth—why wouldn’t they let us make a movie? Why wouldn’t they let this end with a lavish Dracula puppet musical? In my head, it was all so clear. It’s only since then where you become savvy, and you start to understand how it works a little more—and there’s a real risk at becoming less brave. The more experience you get, you’re like, Oh, I don’t know, we should probably test the Dracula puppet musical. And it is not going to pass the test. Kristen, what do you remember about that time?Veronica Marswas a big hit for you, but it got canceled while you were filmingSarah Marshall. Bell:Was it a big hit? Segel:It was a big hit. We were fucking psyched you were coming. Kristen Bell’s coming in! Make no mistake about it: big hit. Bell:Critically, it was great, but no one was watching it—we were always on the bubble. The fans were always doing something insane, like sending dollar bills into the UPN executives’ offices, because there was a dollar bill where I wrote, “I’m Smarter Than You,” and hid it in someone’s locker. They rented a plane and did the letters in the sky. They were crazy. They sent thousands of Mars bars. The fans were the ones making a ruckus about the show. We were always at risk of being canceled, so in no way, shape, or form did I feel secure in my career. I felt very hungry, and I saw this group of people that were doing what Jason’s describing, being bold and authentic and strange and bringing new things to the table. I just wanted to dance with them so badly. I felt, when I got the audition, that this could change everything for me. And it did. It changed the whole trajectory of my career. Do you have any fun off-set memories from filming in Hawaii? Segel:The honest answer is that it was like half a movie and half camp. We cast a couple adults to work at the hotel because, at one point, Nick and I were like, “Is everyone who works at this high-end professional hotel under 25 years old?” But we were all so young and so enthused about making it, and so we were— Bell:Drinking bottles of wine together.Mila [Kunis]brought her video game console.Jack McBrayerstayed four weeks when he worked four days, convinced everyone to keep him there. Every day that we walked to work, he was just at the pool sunbathing. Segel:I’m going to embarrass Jack McBrayer too. He did this thing, which takes such balls. I couldn’t do it. Every morning when he wasn’t shooting, he would come to set with a backpack and load the backpack up with craft service—just a backpack full of snacks—and wave to everyone and leave. Harrison Ford and Jason Segel inShrinking. How hard is it to get the comedy right on your current shows—ShrinkingandNobody Wants This—while balancing drama as well? Bell:I’m very respectful of that process. I’m not a person that comes in and is like, “I know exactly what we should do.” There’s been a writers room thinking about it for six months. I take what’s on the page, and it’s almost like I close my eyes and just feel it. I will read it and then I’ll say it in my head. I don’t know how to articulate how I deliver a line or do comedy. It comes completely and utterly from my gut, and I can tell if it’s working, and I can tell if it’s not. I lean into the things that are working. Then there’s a second phase, which is, I’ll push a boundary here, or I’ll pull one back. I like to hand it to the editors and say, Now you do the emotional math. Segel:The script is like this treasure map. Then this handoff happens where you’re dropped into the treasure map, and it’s three-dimensional, and suddenlyHarrison Fordis looking at you funny and you say, “Why are you looking at me funny?” Then you have this little pocket off to the side, this little pocket of new experience. I think that’s the best version of improv at this stage of my career: As opposed to thinking it’s your job to come in and improve the script, it’s more to be present and to be alive and make sure you don’t miss that something might be happening. Bell:Jason, one thing sticks out really beautifully to me, which was a gift you gave me. We were in the scene on your lanai, and we were having a breakup talk. I was crying, and I couldn’t remember the line because I had a lot of emotion. And you stayed in character and looked at me and fed me the line. It was such a gift, because there wasn’t this big stop, or being left hanging in this abyss where I couldn’t figure out what my next line was. Jason was so connected to our common goal in that scene. He took a chance and knew that maybe if he whispered the first four words of my next sentence, I would click back in. And I did. Segel:I had a similar experience with Kristen where we were doing the nude breakup scene. I was sitting on the couch kind of emoting, and she leaned over and whispered to me, “Close your legs. You don’t want people to see your dick looking like that.” Kristen Bell and Adam Brody inNobody Wants This. What have you learned about acting from your costars onShrinkingandNobody Wants This? Bell:Every single job is the same training experience. I’ve read the script, I think I know where my instincts lie, I come to set, I get to work with someone likeJustine Lupe—who will bring something that I never even saw in the script to life. So I would still describe it as an openness. I am surprised every time I do a scene because I don’t know what’s happening inside the other actor’s head. Sometimes that surprise is amazing, and I immediately agree with it and I think it’s fun. And other times, I really don’t think the scene should go there. I’ve read a scene, and Adam [Brody] is playing it completely differently than how I saw it. It’s a bit of emotional gymnastics for me, but it’s still fun. It’s not negative; it’s just surprising and different. Segel:I think of my job onShrinkinglike a point guard on a basketball team. That’s my job. I have to really pay attention to where my costars want to receive the ball, how they play best. The show is written so that I’m going to get mine—I’m going to get the ball in crucial moments. But most of the time, my job is to set upJessica [Williams], set up Harrison [Ford], make sure that everybody has this chance to thrive. It’s sort of my job to help them create their highlight reel. Bell:That is such a beautiful way to say it. There are some shows you could watch where it feels as though the lead actor is a bit of an energy vampire, and everyone else is just in support. And those aren’t my personal favorite shows to watch. But there’s something inarticulable about the vibe that Jason’s talking about being cognizant of creating. Segel:I had a moment onShrinkingin season one where Harrison was set up to kill, and he fucking killed. Of course he did. But he’s in a slightly new environment of a comedy set, and he got a big laugh from the crew. They yelled “cut,” and Harrison walked by me and—just in the Harrison way that he has—whispered in my ear, “I knew I was fucking funny.” I’ll get to have that forever. As actors, we all have these parts of us that we believe about ourselves that we maybe haven’t gotten the chance to show. I think it’s pretty awesome to set up scenarios where people are pushed a little further than your first thought. Do you feel like you have a side of yourselves you haven’t gotten to show yet? Segel:I crave playing a villain. I feel my whole career, I’ve walked the line between charming and creepy, and then at the very end I tipped charming. But I would really be interested to see what happens when you tip creepy. Those are all the villains that I love: these ones that are charming and funny and creepy, and then turn out to be horrible. Bell:I feel like I love being a mom so much, and there’s such a well of complexity of emotion behind that, when you start living for something else, cellularly, that changes you. And then it’s also a ton of highs and the absolute lowest of the lows—you have this beautiful thing you’re so proud of, but as it gets older, it lives to cut you down. It’s a very turbulent inner world. I’m currently playing a 44-year-old rom-com love interest—I cannot believe they’re letting me do that. But I would like to explore something more into the complexities of motherhood. Even if it weren’t a project about motherhood, but just playing a mother. I feel like it’s a very deep well for me. Segel:Can I just jump in on “44-year-old love interest”? Because I think it’s exactly right. I made a mistake: I was sure my 20s were my prime, because you’re doing all this stuff, and it’s electric, and you’re new at it, and you’re at the top of the world. You’re getting all this attention. And there was a moment where that kind of fizzled out and things got a little smaller. In my mind, my prime had happened. But what I have found, and I certainly see it for you, is that that wasrehearsalfor your prime. That was prime without the depth of experience, without the depth of making it through some shit and coming out the other side. Now I’m in my 40s, doing these scenes onShrinkingthat I couldn’t have done in my 20s. I had no depth of experience about what it’s like to lose somebody, or what it’s like to have your kid go off to college and feel so proud—but also that your heart’s being ripped out of your chest. It makes total sense that you’re the lead in a rom-com right now because you’re the best version of yourself now. title: Donald Trump Is Trying to Tip New Jersey Red
article_text: Donnie from Bedminster is calling on line two! Donnie, go ahead, you’re on the air with Jack! Okay, so this Donnie is the president,Donald Trump,and he’s really from Queens, or Florida, or maybe Washington, DC. But he spends part of the year at hisNew Jersey golf club: “Special place. You know that I stay there all the time. I live there alot.” And he’s calling in to a political rally one week before the state’s gubernatorial primaries. Yet Trump, whatever his means of communication, can’t help but give off serious right-wing talk radio crank vibes. “The radical-left Democrats in the race are woke…lunatics who want New Jersey to be a haven for illegal alien gang members, human traffickers, dangerous criminals of all kinds, including murderers who have been let into our country by Biden and his group of people with their open-border craziness,” Trump says,his rantgaining speed, if not coherence. “And if you get four more years with somebody that you’ve been going through, I mean, it’s just so sad. Your taxes go up. You crush the middle-class families and cause mass exodus. And that’s happened. Mass exodus of jobs and businesses all throughout the state while they indoctrinate your children at a public school. It’s a terrible thing that happens to the children. You look and hear and all—it’s called transgender for all, and we’ve ended that. New Jersey’s economy will wither and die, and you’ll be living in a nightmare of chaos and crime, and you sort of have that to a certain extent now.” The beneficiary of this tirade isJack Ciattarelli,the front-runner for the Republican nomination in the New Jersey governor’s race. Ciattarelli, a former state legislator wholostby just more than three percentage points in 2021, has a commanding lead in the GOP primary largely because of his shift from Trump skeptic to Trump worshipper. “I’m so very grateful for his complete and total endorsement,” Ciattarelli gushes when Trump lets him get in a word. “Mr. President, thank you. I so very much appreciate your faith, your trust, your confidence. And I know none of us are surprised here, since New Jersey’s kind of your summer home, how in tune you are with the issues that matter to all New Jerseyans.” Sucking up to Trump is standard in Republican politics these days. What’s less certain—and what’s likely to determine both the Democratic nomineenext weekand the winner in November’s general election—is just how big a role Trump ends up playing with New Jersey voters. The crowded field of Democratic contenders to succeed incumbent governorPhil Murphy,who is term-limited after eight years in office, has come at the Trump problem from a variety of angles.Steve Fulop,the mayor of Jersey City, has used a broad antiestablishment, policy-geek message to climb to second in recent polls, where he’s tied withRas Baraka,the mayor of Newark, andJosh Gottheimer,a combative, centrist congressman. Of the six candidates, Baraka is the furthest left, ideologically, and the most strenuously anti-Trump, stylistically. He recently visited a new federal migrant deportation facility and was arrested by Homeland Security agents; Baraka isnow suingthe interim US attorney for New Jersey,Alina Habba,a close Trump ally. Regardless of whether Baraka intended to be detained, the confrontation earned him a bonanza of media attention. “I think he did a very smart thing by getting arrested,” saysJulie Roginsky,a Democratic strategist who was the main architect of Murphy’s 2017 campaign before a bitter falling-out with his team. “It gave him a tremendous amount of national exposure at just the right time.” If Baraka wins, he will set up a polar general election contrast to the MAGA Ciattarelli. The consistent Democratic front-runner,Mikie Sherrill,has so far pulled off a deft balancing act. The former Navy pilot was elected to Congress as part of the 2018 “blue wave” reaction to Trump’s first win. And during the current campaign, Sherrill has at times been passionate in expressing her opposition to the president, appearing to wipe away a tear when speaking about immigration policy during a candidate forum at Rutgers University. “As a country, we’ve been really dedicated to the democratic ideals of delivering opportunity. That it doesn’t matter who your parents were or where you were born or how much money you have, but it’s what you can make of yourself,” Sherrill tells me just after shaking hands with voters at a diner in Hamilton Township while battling a migraine. “The Trump administration is trying to shut down those opportunities for people across the country and especially people here in New Jersey.” Sherrill calls Trump “a huge factor” in the race, but she has been careful not to become a one-note anti-Trump candidate—regularly emphasizing, for instance, her plans to lower utility bills and housing costs. She has assembled formidable support from the state’s powerful county organizations; Sherrill has also come across as providing the closest thing to a continuation of Murphy’s agenda, a posture that could cut either way. “Anybody who wants to be governor is going to have to be strong and be willing to stand up to President Trump’s administration as they attack the things we care about here, willing to take them to court, as Jack Ciattarelli has vowed not to,” she tells me. “But at the same time, I think it’s incumbent upon the next governor to deliver for families, to drive down costs here.” Sherrill has tried to avoid taking any positions that might come back to haunt her in a general election matchup with Ciattarelli, should she win the Democratic nomination next week. “For a Republican to win in New Jersey, Democrats have to screw up so much to make Democratic voters hold their nose and vote for a Republican candidate,” Roginsky says. “That’s what happened withChris Christiein 2009, that’s what happened withChristie Todd Whitmanin 1993. Then again, we’ve never had a Donald Trump before.” Registered Democrats still outnumber Republicans in New Jersey, but the second-biggest bloc is independents, and last year Trump lost the state toKamala Harrisby just less than six points. Trump’s approval in the reliably blue state clocked in at 47% ina recent poll, which is just above thenational average, and he has a particularly strong base in south Jersey. “I can’t imagine the Republicans believe they can win the governor’s race in Virginia—Trump has laid off half the state by now,” a New Jersey Democratic strategist says, referring to major cuts to the federal workforce. “So if they think they can win here, do they pour a hundred million dollars in crypto into the campaign? Ciattarelli is a good politician. For us, the message is going to boil down to: ‘We have to stop Trump here in New Jersey.’” Next week’s primary results should show who voters think is best equipped to not only lower their property taxes, but also stand up to the bully from Bedminster. title: 1 in 4 Hongkongers unaware of coming public healthcare fee changes: survey
article_text: Lawmakers call on authorities to ramp up efforts to promote reform, set to come into force in January 2026 One in four Hongkongers is unaware of the expansion of a medical fee waiver mechanism, a survey has found, with lawmakers urging the government to ramp up efforts to promote the public healthcare subsidy regime reform set to be implemented in six months. The survey, involving 724 respondents and conducted by the city’s largest workers’ union between April 22 and May 13, showed that some participants lacked a clear understanding of the measures that were aimed at broadening the safety net in public hospitals. Lawmaker Stanley Ng Chau-pei, president of the Federation of Trade Unions, said residents were more familiar with the measures related to fee increases, including in accident and emergency (A&E) rooms, and general outpatient clinics. “When residents have a limited understanding of the reform, how can the government effectively implement the measures?” he said. “The government should ramp up its efforts to promote the reform, especially in areas concerning how it will increase support for patients.” The survey found 29 per cent of respondents did not know about the relaxation of income and asset limits of the fee waiver mechanism, while about a quarter had no idea about the HK$10,000 (US$1,274) cap on annual spending for public healthcare services.

title: Hong Kong leader orders ageing water pipes lined with bitumen to be replaced
article_text: John Lee outlines 10 measures to address concerns over black particles found in water supply at two public housing estates Hong Kong’s leader has ordered authorities to replace hundreds of metres of bitumen-lined pipes as one of 10 measures to address residents’ concerns over black particles dirtying the water at two public housing estates. Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu weighed in on Friday, a week after initial reports of the particles emerged, as he tasked Deputy Financial Secretary Michael Wong Wai-lun with supervising the implementation of the measures. Government test results on Thursday confirmed that the particles found in the freshwater supply at Queens Hill Estate and Shan Lai Court in Fanling were bitumen, a substance produced through the distillation of crude oil and known for its waterproofing and adhesive properties. It has been banned from use in water pipes since 2005, but authorities have stressed that the water remains safe to consume. “I am highly concerned about the freshwater incident at Queens Hill Estate and Shan Lai Court, and I convened a high-level meeting [on Friday] afternoon,” Lee wrote on his social media page. “The government is responsible to ensure the public can safely consume freshwater, and the incident must be handled quickly and the public concern can be thoroughly eased.”
